title: What To Do in San Francisco
name: What To Do in San Francisco
description:
A Map by Bkingbking

Off-the-beaten track for hiking/walking activities, places to eat, places to people watch, and other things not readily known by tourists.  It's a work in progress.

properties.name: Corona Heights Park
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking  roosevelt way & museum way san francisco, caIf you want to get a great view of the downtown San Francisco, Oakland, and the East Bay, but you don\'t have a lot of time or have small kids, this is a five minute hike to the top. There are two playgrounds within five minutes along with several tennis courts. Check it out at night, as well. It\'s a five minute drive from Tank Hill. The image is the view of Corona Heights by a San Francisco artist named Mary Proenza.

properties.name: Crissy Field
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking  Great spot to watch ocean-going ships, sailboats, windsurfers, kitesailers, hike, run, bike, rollerblade, picnic . . . you name it. It\'s one of the most amazing things about San Francisco. Right in the middle of a big city is a park with unbelievable physical beauty. Crissy Field used to be the airfield associated with The Presidio. Lot\'s of history and other cool things to do that are nearby. There\'s a cool evening picture of Crissy Field by David Sanger, along with some other photos I found on Flickr or the web.

properties.name: Golden Gate Park
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking   9th Avenue at Lincoln Way San Francisco, CA 94122Golden Gate Park is enormous with everything from botanical gardens, playground, paddle boats (Stow Lake) polo grounds, lawn bowling, croquet, windmills, buffalo, fly fishing practice areas, exotic flower conservatory, tennis, model boat clubs (including submarines and speedboats that go 50mph!), Japanese tea garden, golf, outdoor theatre, concerts, and walking distance to the 9th & Irving, Cole Valley and Haight neighborhoods where you can grab a coffee, burrito, or sit down to eat. I generally recommend people to start their tour of Golden Gate Park in the Botanical Gardens. It\'s a good reference point to begin your exploration. Several main roads in the park are closed on Sundays -- which is great for walkers, bikers, bladers, strollers, etc to have more room -- so parking may be more difficult.

properties.name: Mama's on Washington Square
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking 1701 Stockton St, San Francisco, CABest breakfast in San Francisco. Best pancakes anywhere. Get there early as the line starts to form quickly.

properties.name: Pesce
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking 2227 Polk St, San Francisco, CAGreat seafood restaurant in Russian Hill. The salmon with spinach is excellent and reasonably priced. There are tons of other restaurants and bars on the same 2-block area. Great neighborhood.

properties.name: Tank Hill
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking  shrader and belgrave, san francisco, caTank Hill is above Cole Valley and near the Castro Haight-Ashbury neighborhoods. It\'s a five minute hike but the views of downtown San Francisco, Golden Gate Bridge, and looking up the Pacific coastline are great. It\'s called Tank Hill because there used to be a water tank there in the 1880\'s or so. If you are limited on time but want to get outside and get some great views, then this is a great spot. Check it out at night, as well. It\'s a five minute drive from Corona Heights Park.

properties.name: The Grove (Fillmore)
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking  2016 Fillmore Street, San Francisco, CA 94115Fun breakfast and light dinner place. The oatmeal is the thing to get in the morning. Great place to people watch.

properties.name: The Grove (Marina)
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking  2250 Chestnut Street, San Francisco, CA 94123Fun breakfast and light dinner place. The oatmeal is the thing to get in the morning. Great place to people watch.

properties.name: Via Vai
properties.description: Posted by Bkingbking 1715 Union Street, San Francisco, CA 94123Great, family run Italian restaurant. Prices are reasonable, the atmosphere is always festive yet understated, and the food is excellent. We used to live 3-4 blocks away and never had a bad meal or experience.
